evidence.text: The United States seeks a declaratory judgment that Idaho’s law is invalid under the Supremacy Clause and is preempted by federal law to the extent that it conflicts with EMTALA.
The United States also seeks an order preliminarily and permanently enjoining Idaho’s restrictive abortion law to the extent it conflicts with EMTALA.
Under the Emergency Medical Treatment and Labor Act (EMTALA), 42 U.S.C. § 1395dd
EMTALA contains an express preemption provision, which preempts State laws “to the extent that the requirement directly conflicts with a requirement of this section.” 42 U.S.C. § 1395dd(f)
The law, codified at Idaho Code § 18-622, is currently set to take effect on August 25, 2022
The United States seeks a declaratory judgment that Idaho’s law is invalid under the Supremacy Clause and is preempted by federal law to the extent that it conflicts with EMTALA.
a declaratory judgment that Idaho Code § 18-622 violates the Supremacy Clause and is preempted by federal law to the extent that it conflicts with EMTALA

evidence.text: a preliminary and permanent injunction against the State of Idaho—including all of its officers, employees, and agents—prohibiting enforcement of Idaho Code § 18-622(2)-(3) to the extent that it conflicts with EMTALA

add_extracted.value: Preliminary and permanent injunction against the State of Idaho prohibiting enforcement of Idaho Code § 18-622(2)-(3) to the extent it conflicts with EMTALA

evidence.text: In this action, the United States seeks a declaratory judgment that Idaho’s law is invalid under the Supremacy Clause and is preempted by federal law to the extent that it conflicts with EMTALA. The law, codified at Idaho Code § 18-622, is currently set to take effect on August 25, 2022, which is 30 days after the Supreme Court’s decision in Dobbs v. Jackson Women’s Health Organization, 142 S. Ct. 2228 (2022).

add_extracted.value: Idaho’s abortion law, effective August 25, 2022, criminalizes abortions and conflicts with EMTALA’s requirement to provide stabilizing medical treatment for patients in emergency situations.

evidence.text: PRELIMINARY INJUNCTION
IT IS ORDERED ... DENIED
The panel granted the Idaho Legislature’s motion to stay, pending appeal, the district court’s order preliminarily enjoining Idaho Code section 18-622
